decks.title: Discover Bhutan
decks.description: Explore Bhutan's unique culture and policies.

cards.heading: Bhutan's Unique Governance
cards.body: Bhutan is the world's last Buddhist kingdom, with a king who is deeply loved by his people. During Covid, he supported 50,000 people in the tourism industry with personal funds, almost reaching personal bankruptcy.

cards.heading: Gross National Happiness
cards.body: In 1972, Bhutan adopted Gross National Happiness as a national policy, prioritizing happiness over economic growth. Despite being unconventional, this policy has made Bhutan famous for its happiness-focused governance.

cards.heading: Carbon-Negative Bhutan
cards.body: Bhutan is the only carbon-negative country in the world, thanks to its vast forests that absorb more CO2 than the country emits. This conservation effort is part of their dedication to preserving the environment.

cards.heading: Cultural Preservation in Bhutan
cards.body: Bhutan fiercely preserves its traditional way of life, having banned TV and internet until 1999. Tourism is limited to guided tours, and immigration is nearly impossible to maintain cultural integrity.

cards.heading: The Future: Gelephu Mindfulness City
cards.body: To address youth migration, Bhutan plans to build Gelephu Mindfulness City, an economic hub focused on innovation while preserving tradition. The project, however, might take 20 years to complete.

decks.title: Understanding Toddlers
decks.description: Humor and insights on living with toddlers.

cards.heading: Love and Boredom
cards.body: Parents can feel deep love and simultaneous boredom with their toddlers. While the joy from a hug or a smile is immense, spending hours with a toddler can sometimes feel monotonous due to their limited conversational skills.

cards.heading: Dictators in Diapers
cards.body: Toddlers can behave like little dictators, displaying strong will and stubbornness. They often have a one-track mind and can be hilariously blunt, such as when they dismissively suggest parents go work instead of playing with them.

cards.heading: Language Sponges
cards.body: Toddlers are linguistic geniuses, rapidly acquiring language skills just by exposure. Despite their impressive ability to learn languages, they often make funny errors in understanding pronouns or sentence structures.

cards.heading: Worldview: A Toddler's Reality
cards.body: Toddlers have an inaccurate view of the world, often believing it revolves around them. This is a result of their limited life experiences where everything is new and tailored to their needs.

cards.heading: Unintentional Comedians
cards.body: Toddlers can be unintentionally hilarious. They often mimic funny phrases or actions without understanding the humor, providing endless amusement for parents.

cards.heading: Judgment Among Parents
cards.body: Parenting toddlers is filled with strong opinions and judgment from others. It’s important for parents to focus on enjoying time with their children and fostering their natural development rather than adhering strictly to others' opinions.

decks.title: Journey Through VR
decks.description: Explore the evolution of VR with Vision Pro.

cards.heading: VR's Early Days
cards.body: In 1990, virtual reality was a novel but fleeting experience. The initial excitement of stepping into a cartoon world faded as VR technology went dormant for 25 years. This resurgence in the mid-2010s reignited interest, thanks to innovators like Palmer Luckey and companies like Oculus.

cards.heading: Apple's Vision Pro Debut
cards.body: Apple introduced the Vision Pro in 2023, branding it as a 'spatial computing' device. Priced at $3,500, it promised a new era of immersive experiences, though initial reactions were tempered by the high cost and limited applications.

cards.heading: Holy Shit Moments
cards.body: The Vision Pro provided a 'holy shit moment' reminiscent of the first iPhone's debut. These moments often precede significant industry shifts, though VR's history suggests caution in predicting immediate mass adoption.

cards.heading: Challenges with VR Adoption
cards.body: Despite VR's jaw-dropping demos, it struggles to hook users long-term. Issues include the solo nature of experiences, friction in setup, and a reliance on novelty, which may hinder widespread adoption.

cards.heading: Vision Pro's Interface Innovation
cards.body: Vision Pro's intuitive 'eye pinch' interface allows users to interact seamlessly with apps in space. This innovation could set a new standard for VR/AR interfaces, much like the iPhone did for smartphones.

cards.heading: VR's Potential and Limitations
cards.body: While the Vision Pro hints at a revolutionary future, its current offerings remain limited. The potential for spatial computing is vast, but realizing it will require time, innovation, and broader app development.

decks.title: Insights from New Parenthood
decks.description: Humorous insights into the early days of parenting.

cards.heading: Newborns: Not Quite Babies
cards.body: A newborn is more like a bizarre human larva than a baby. Due to evolutionary constraints, humans are born prematurely compared to other species, which means the first few months are like an extension of the womb experience. This explains why newborns act so weird and seem not quite ready for the world.

cards.heading: Lack of Parenthood Training
cards.body: Unlike driving or practicing medicine, becoming a parent comes with no mandatory training. New parents are expected to figure things out on their own. This raises the question of whether a short course on newborn care should be mandatory, as societal expectations often don't match the reality of parenting.

cards.heading: Dramatic Baby Behavior
cards.body: Babies express their needs in exaggerated ways, turning minor discomforts into Shakespearean-level dramas. A hungry or tired baby might seem in agony, yet a simple burp can instantly transform them into a picture of calmness. This can be both frustrating and amusing for new parents.

cards.heading: Parental Love: A One-Sided Affair
cards.body: In the early stages, parental love is intensely one-sided. Parents have deep affection for their newborns, but there's little reciprocation from the baby, who is yet to develop consciousness. This can make the initial bonding period uniquely challenging and rewarding.

cards.heading: The Chaos of Baby Schedules
cards.body: Newborns disrupt any semblance of a routine, as their sleep and feeding patterns are unpredictable. This lack of structure can be challenging for new parents, who must adapt to a constantly changing schedule dictated by their baby's needs.

cards.heading: The Long Transition to Parenthood
cards.body: Becoming a parent doesn't happen overnight; it's a gradual process as your baby grows and changes. Initially, you might not feel like a 'parent,' but as your child develops and your role evolves, the identity of parenthood takes shape.

decks.title: Curious Minds Mailbag
decks.description: Dive into fascinating questions and insights.

cards.heading: Seeing Germs
cards.body: To see germs, you'd need 640,000 of a virus like COVID-19 to form a visible speck. A virus is about 120nm, but visible objects need to be at least 0.1mm, the width of a human hair.

cards.heading: Bacteria Mass on Earth
cards.body: If all the bacteria on Earth were clumped together, it would form a cube 15km wide, covering much of Los Angeles and rising higher than airplanes fly. Spread out, it would coat Earth in a 7mm layer.

cards.heading: Why Old Songs Appeal
cards.body: We often re-listen to songs because our brains enjoy the familiarity of their 'dance steps,' creating pleasure pathways. In contrast, films are exciting due to plot uncertainty.

cards.heading: Sleep Solutions
cards.body: Tim Urban combats insomnia by using a distraction like reading or listening to podcasts, avoiding stimulating activities on his phone. He uses an old phone for bedtime reading to avoid distractions.

cards.heading: Art vs. Artist
cards.body: Loving art doesn’t mean endorsing the artist's actions. Many great artists had flawed characters, but their work can still hold value and meaning.

cards.heading: NYC's Unique Charm
cards.body: New York City offers unparalleled diversity in culture and industry, making it a vibrant place to live despite its challenges.

decks.title: Exploring the Universe
decks.description: Dive into the scale of the universe.

cards.heading: The Fun Room Concept
cards.body: Tim Urban describes the 'fun room' as a mental space where he explores ideas about the universe's scale. It's a place for creative exploration and collaboration with like-minded individuals, such as Philipp Dettmer from Kurzgesagt.

cards.heading: Kurzgesagt Collaboration
cards.body: The collaboration between Tim Urban and Philipp Dettmer led to adapting Wait But Why content into Kurzgesagt's animated videos. This shows how different mediums can enhance educational content.

cards.heading: Universe in a Nutshell
cards.body: The 'Universe in a Nutshell' app was created to explore the scale of the universe. It includes 250 objects, over 30,000 words of explanations, and dynamic illustrations, providing a unique educational experience.

cards.heading: Exploring Scale
cards.body: The app's interface is a giant high-resolution wall that allows users to explore objects from galaxies to subatomic particles. This innovative design helps users grasp the vastness and intricacies of the universe.

cards.heading: Feedback for Growth
cards.body: The developers encourage user feedback to improve the app, emphasizing a continuous enhancement mindset. This approach ensures the app evolves with user needs and educational trends.

decks.title: Time's Strange Perspectives
decks.description: Explore how the past feels closer than it is.

cards.heading: The 1920s Then and Now
cards.body: We see the 2020s as a futuristic decade, just as people in the 1920s did with their '20s. History repeats itself in fascinating ways, showing how our perception of time shapes our understanding of the present and past.

cards.heading: World Wars' Time Proximity
cards.body: If WWII started today, WWI would feel as distant as 9/11 does to us now. This highlights how historical events can feel both distant and recent simultaneously, depending on our personal and generational perspectives.

cards.heading: The Wonder Years Time Shift
cards.body: The Wonder Years TV show depicted 1968-1973. If recreated today, it would cover 2000-2005. This highlights how our perception of 'recent history' shifts as we age, making past decades feel both near and far.

cards.heading: Movies Closer to History
cards.body: Movies like Jurassic Park, The Lion King, and Forrest Gump, released closer to the moon landing than to today, show how rapidly time moves, and how cultural icons can span generations.

cards.heading: Generational Time Distortion
cards.body: For today’s kids, 9/11 is akin to the moon landing for those born in the 1980s. This demonstrates how each generation has its unique historical anchors, shaping its collective memory and identity.

cards.heading: The 2100s and Today’s Youth
cards.body: Most kids today will live to see the 2100s, emphasizing how time continues to march forward, connecting generations in ways that feel both profound and surreal.
